title: Counterfeit  N95 Masks  Seized From  Warehouse  ----  By Deanna Paul
text:
New York City authorities raided a Long Island City warehouse that they said held 1.7 million counterfeit N95 masks, marking one of the biggest single seizures of personal protective equipment since the pandemic began.

The Queens County District Attorney's Office, which spearheaded the investigation, charged Zhi Zeng, the warehouse manager, with felony trademark counterfeiting on Wednesday. If convicted, the 33-year-old Brooklyn man faces up to 15 years in prison. Other individuals are under investigation.

Authorities said the warehouse was "an elaborate production assembly line" for the counterfeit masks. They also found hundreds of thousands of pieces of other personal protective equipment in the warehouse.

"We are living in a horrible pandemic with more than 450,000 Americans dead from Covid-19. This defendant allegedly sold false hope and security and was set to sell more of these counterfeit masks," said Queens District Attorney Melinda Katz.

Acting on a tip, law enforcement raided the two-story warehouse in Long Island City this week, and discovered more than 100 pallets "piled high with boxes of 3M-labeled N95 masks," according to the district attorney's office. Mr. Zeng, who pleaded not guilty Wednesday, was present at the time.

3M Co. is a manufacturer of N95 masks, which have emerged as critical protective tools for healthcare workers. A 3M spokeswoman said the company assisted the Queens prosecutors' probe and has launched a global effort to fight fraud.

The Queens District Attorney's Office is working to identify anyone who may have purchased or used the counterfeit masks that were already distributed.

---

Austen Hufford contributed to this article.
